displayed_text: Patient: Four. Doctor: Argh! I can’t even trip him off. Family Member: I know. I know. Doctor: Well… you might need chemo. Let me say that again. You might need chemo. Was that whiney enough for you? Family Member: Yeah. Well, at least you have something. You could’ve came in here and said, “Oh, we got nothing for you. Doctor: Oh no, I got tons of stuff for you. The question is when and how and how do you feel about that. Family Member: S___? Patient: I can live with it if I can do the infusion stuff up there. Doctor: Okay. That's a possibility. However, as anything else, we actually have a study. Half the group gets regular chemo, which is IV. The other group gets a pill chemo which is oral. I can't tell you which one you are. And of course, we need you to commit so that if you say there's no freakin way I'm gonna get chemo down here then don't do the trial, but it's a fifty-fifty Family Member: You don't want to come down here xxx do you? Patient: How often do I have to be here? Doctor: Well, chemo is once every three weeks. So if you're good, don't quote me because I botched up a thousand things today in terms of the schedule, which is why I keep my mouth shut half the time. But standard chemo is once every three weeks. Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad.

Family Member: To qualify for that. Patient: What do they do? Doctor: Oh, no. That’s a specialized scan. Yeah. I mean, he would definitely need a blood draw and all that. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All that screening would happen here. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Then, we schedule that trip. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? And on that scan, if it looks like your cancer is expressing the PSMA, then we would start looking into whether we, uh, you know, then we can put you on the study. Because if it does- if your cancer cells are not expressing that antigen, I wouldn’t even bother going that way because what’s the point? Patient: Right. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, even after you get enrolled on it, though, there is a one in three chance that you may not get the actual treatment.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: But we do need to get you on that XGEVA that we had talked about. Family Member: Yeah chickles]]. Doctor: And you know every time. So today I have to see if they’re ready with it because then we might as well do that injection today. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because that is what most effected in countering both bone metastasis as well as the the- Family Member: Right. Patient: But if you’re not ready today I can get that back home too. Doctor: -bone weakness. Yeah you can. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: With a prescription. I was reading up on the prostate cancer in the bone and they recommended not – a diet low in calcium for that. Do you know anything about that? Doctor: No I think for a while people were maxing out and taking crazy high amounts of calcium. So that is not recommended because they actually found a worse outcome with that.

Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s not a whole lot, uh, for change. And your scans have not shown any major change. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know? The ones she did in, uh, end of November or December, whenever you saw her last. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, so based on that, I wouldn’t change anything. I think you should stick with, uh, the Lupron should be continued and the bone medication. Are they doing both of those? Family Member: Yeah. Today he gets- he gets his next Lupron February twelfth. Doctor: Okay. And what about the (Xgeva) Family Member: Uh-uh. Doctor: That may be helpful. So I’ll, uh, send a note to her. There is a bone-strengthening medication. Family Member: He’s seen a, uh, do you need to see your dentist before you-? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. That kind of stuff. But, uh, but it can be very helpful, especially because the hormone therapy all this time has, can weaken the bones. So, so this may be something that will help, uh, and sometimes it can help with the bone pain, too, uh. You know? So I think all around it’s a good idea to get that started.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: -the first week of January.So, and, that’s, you know, reality is probably mid-January, I would imagine. Patient: Okay, well then… Doctor: Okay? Patient: We are leaving town on the… Family Member: The twelfth. Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then. Doctor: Okay. Let’s, we’ll incorporate that all in. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s all. Or, if we have to, then we will start the twenty-first when you come back or the twenty-second. Patient: Gotcha. Okay. Family Member: Mm-hmm.

Healthcare Professional 1: So did you make another appointment to see Dr. G____? Patient: Yeah uh uhhh… Doctor: Okay so they gave you enough? Patient: I think she said March – March, March something, March twenty-third or something. Doctor: Okay, alright. Patient: Twenty-second, twenty-third. Doctor: Let’s see what he finds. Okay so… Patient: I hope he don’t find nothing.
DOC Well good point. (Laughs) Doctor: This is your copy of the chemo consent. Okay? Alright so go over and we’ll go ahead with your treatment and you got all your scripts then. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: Everything else went electronically other that what you have in your hand. Okay?

Patient: though too and this question that - Doctor: remember this is a marathon race. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can’t sprint from thing to thing you’ll be exhausted – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and we won’t go anywhere. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we’re pacing you. Mm,hmm. Family Member: So, we’ve got four or five more chemos… Doctor: Yeah I think… Family Member: And then we’ll do a scan? Patient: Did you count this as one? Doctor: That was one. So I think we just need to sort of…

Family Member: He’s scheduled today. Doctor: Oh you’re scheduled today, yes. Patient: One o’clock. Doctor: So you’ll get that today but we generally start the, we have to put in for the Zytiga to get approved; we have to put in the chemo to get approved. It takes a couple of weeks to do all that. So we would start all of that sort of in you know mid-January. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Family Member 1: Yeah, I don’t have any additional questions. Doctor: Great. Patient: There you go. Thank you. Family Member: I have a very basic question. Doctor: Of course. Family Member: What does cure mean?

Family Member: Ohhhh. Doctor: - outside that prostate gland. So it’s raising in my mind a good dilemma whether to do something for it or not. Patient: Uh huh. Okay. Doctor: On the one hand we have where if it keeps on growing it’s going to cause you major obstruction, blockage, things like that (pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And since you don’t have disease; you know if you had disease in twenty spots which is most people in this situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - with this kind of cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We would say forget why are we even bothering to putting you in harm’s way or side effects way – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - by trying to just take care of the prostate when everything else is out there. Patient: Right.

Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds. Doctor: Now are you still trying to be as active as possible, for example, golf or other activities? Or has that been slowing you down? Patient: I’m trying, but I just don’t have the energy. Doctor: Okay, uh any other issues with hot flashes or night sweats? Patient: No, no. Not night sweats, but I do recognize that at times I’m sitting in church and for some reason I just start where other folks are you know are just perfectly calm and cool. Doctor: So during the day just out of the blue? Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops. Doctor: Okay, on an average day how many times does that happen or is it not every day? Patient: When I’ve noticed it, it might be once or twice a day. Doctor: Okay, all right. Usually not at night, usually during the day. Patient: No, no. Well it could be the stress or the activity that’s happening in church that might push my level. Doctor: Well your testosterone level is still low. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Both sides, and - Doctor: All right. Patient: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Still having constipation issues? Come and go? Patient: Of course (chuckles) Doctor: Okay, so with the chemo now, the things to keep track of any kind of fevers, infections, anything I need to know right away. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Now what’s the best way to - Doctor: Get in touch with me? So one-eight hundred_____. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And you ask them to page me. Family Member: All right.

Family Member: No. Doctor: No. No. That’s the Zytiga drug. We’re going to table that for now. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. One is a random study, study, so it’s like a, there’s a possibility you just get the standard, the drug. The other I think- Family Member: You get both? Doctor: You get both. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know?

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: One of the things we have been interested in is how do we make this drug work better and longer. Okay. And one way to make this drug better, work better and longer is to try to combine it with a second drug that’s experimental. Okay. So the Xtandi itself is not experimental, this has been approved by the FDA more than five years ago. It’s standard, does not require you to participate in a clinical trial and I could just write you a prescription for this medication. The experimental clinical trial that we’re doing which is research, so you would have to sign a permission slip which we call a consent form. Not today but after we’ve had time to look at it. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um and I’ll just flip the page to the back. Okay. It’s a randomized trial. What does randomized mean? Randomized means that at the beginning of the study we flip a coin. Might sound crazy. Doctor: So, I’m going to write randomized. And that coin flip is random. In other words, neither the doctor nor the patient can influence it. We can’t rig the system. Once the coin has been flipped, we can’t flip it again. We can’t keep flipping it until we get the one that we want. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So in this study there are two options. One option is patients get the Xtandi. That’s the same thing that I’ve written on the the top of this page. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Okay. So option number one is to get the same drug that I would have recommended anyway as part of your standard care. Option number two is the combination of Xtandi plus the new experimental drug, which has a long name. It’s called G__?___. And this second drug has been shown in the laboratory, not yet in patients but in the laboratory, that makes the Xtandi work better and longer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And one of the things that this drug does, although it does many other things as well, is that it can boost the immune system. So one of the reasons why cancer can grow and progress in a person’s body, is because the immune system isn’t able to attack and kill the cancer cells fast enough. And the cancer cells can make some chemicals that can switch off those immune cells. recognizing and killing the cancer. What this drug is it tries to stimulate that immune system again so it can recognize the cancer. But it does that in conjunction with the Xtandi. Now, I didn’t mention this before but this medication is also a pill. Patient: Okay.

Patient: So, I say, yeah, I tell her can she get a script so I can call my insurance and see where I can get a cheap one at. Doctor: Yeah. I don’t think I will be able to justify a scooter for you. Okay? Based on just this disease. Believe me, I have given that script to other people, and it has not worked for people who are sick or older than you. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, I don’t think it will work. Okay? Uh, beyond that, if you want to see a neurologist, get tested, and see if they would be willing to give you, that’s perfectly okay with me. Patient: Uh, what, a what? Doctor: Neurologist. A nerve specialist. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they have to show that either your nerves are not working, your, uh, legs are not working, something or the other before we Patient: I wonder why they ain’t working good. Doctor: Yeah. So, they will say, “Did you try a walker? Did you try a this or that?” Patient: I, I, uh got a cane. I had a walker. Doctor: Okay. Now,

Patient: To get going? Doctor: A week or two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, it will take a week or two for you to meet up with him and then we’re off and running so soon. Patient: Okay and they do the scheduling? Doctor: Yeah then it’s all them. Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us.
